note.body: Nice, thank you. :thumbsup:

The same [signal is connected](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-commander/-/blob/master/src/layout/color_themes.rs?ref_type=heads#L196-203).

The object of class `ColorThemes` is a singleton owned by `MainWindow`. It listens to `"theme"` changes and reloads CSS (where majority of theme-related code should go). It also emits it's own `theme-changed`, so main window may queue redrawing.

`ColorThemes` has a property `provider` which holds the provider it added to `GdkDisplay` last time via `gtk_style_context_add_provider_for_display`. When `theme` settings is changes it removes the provider, generates new CSS, creates a new provider and adds it to a display. https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-commander/-/blob/master/src/layout/color_themes.rs?ref_type=heads#L227-253

The rest of the code in the `ColorThemes` class is just boilerplate.
Looking good. Merging.

Just for my understanding, where are those signals connected now in the code? I see that changing the color-theme externally from the dconf-editor still works on the fly, but I want to understand how it works now. :)

note.body:
Hey Andrey,

I did not mean to insult you. Your work with gnome commander is very much appreciated. 

In the past I tried to improve the code myself, but my programming skills are far from being good enough to do the transition from Gtk2 to Gtk3. So I'm very sorry if you felt attacked. This was not intended. My guess being Rust the cause of the error was just a rough look into a crystal ball. I'm glad that this guess was not correct.

Please accept my apology.

Best regards

Stefan

@schollsky 

> Is this due to using Rust now?

I feel the need to answer this.

At the beginning of the 2024 this application was based on a Gtk+ 2 and had a ton of code which used widgets and features which were deprecated withing Gtk+'s 2nd version. Last version of Gtk+ 2 was released in 2010.

It took around 4 months of a full-time work to bring the app to Gtk 3 and release 1.18.x.

And now we are moving this app further to Gtk 4 and, who knows, maybe libAdwaita. And the leap from Gtk 3 too Gtk 4 is a bigger deal than Gtk+2 to Gtk 3 transition. It implies 100% asynchronous work of an app. So, to be clear, Rust was a **key factor** to make this happen, to bring the app from 2010 to 2024.

The app may still have some feature gaps and some things broken during the transition, but I aim to keep the piece of Linux and GNOME history (hats off) available for new generations of users.

</end of the rant>

@schollsky I am happy that people are using Gnome Commander and a feedback like yours is very important and valuable.

I cannot reproduce the issue (I don't have such populated folders on my machine). But there is a thing I suspect to be a cause of a slowness.

Sorting routine is too defensive and pessimistic. It [re-queries file info](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-commander/-/blob/master/src/gnome-cmd-file-list.cc?ref_type=heads#L1027-1038) on every iteration while `GnomeCmdFile` objects [have it cached](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-commander/-/blob/master/libgcmd/gnome-cmd-file-base.h?ref_type=heads#L39-40). That seems to be a right thing to do dealing with a remote FS, but it seems redundant for a local one.

Hi Uwe,

I did as you suggested. The prior version from commit d9a82cdf actually displays directories with a large number of folders or files very fast - so it seems you were right with the sort condition as suspect.

Can you give it a try to checkout commit `d9a82cdf` and test the same behavior? The change after that was added just two days ago. Reason is, after this commit in the master branch, I added an additional sort condition in the file list. This one should find out if a file is actually a (broken) symlink before the real sorting happens. It might be that this change is influencing the time for listing the directory (although I would be surprised).

If not, maybe @andy128k can comment here. ;-)
I can confirm that. But I found a workaround: hitting `Ctrl+Enter` works.

note.body:
Unrelated to this MR: 

It took me some days... Maybe it is interesting for you as well: Had the problem that when changing a file in VSCode and compiling it, the debugger (or better VSCode) did not realize that my file has actually changed before compilation, but meson did. As a result, I could not add breakpoints for new code that I just added. Also code which was just commented out was still used when debugging... Totally confusing!

After some fiddling I overcame this situation by adding `meson setup --reconfigure builddir` in tasks.json like this:

```
{
    "tasks": [
        {
            "label": "build debug meson",
            "type": "shell",
            "command": "meson setup --reconfigure builddir && meson compile -C builddir"
        },
    ],
    "version": "2.0.0"
}
```

This is actually strange, because the reconfigure option should only have an effect if "new options have been added to the project and the default value is not working." [link to documentation](https://mesonbuild.com/Commands.html).

Just writing this down here in case you have the same issue...

note.body: You're right, I only assumed that the widget port was done as I'd expect when GTK 4 was born. So, yes, this MR does not introduce any a11y semantic changes. I'd still add the role to the viewer status bars, but in a separate MR, very likely. I would hope that the progress bar in the search window is not ignored by Orca, but I did not try.
It seems like we aren't loosing anything in terms of a11y by switching from `GtkStatusbar` to any other widget.

## Search dialog

The status widget has a progress bar (which I guess has its own a11y announce) and a label saying "Found X matches" which is updated every 100ms.

## Viewer dialog (text mode)

The status widget displays scroll position, line wrap mode, encoding etc.

## Viewer dialog (image mode)

The status widget displays image size and current scale.

---

What disturbs me is that Gtk documentation advises [against using this widget](https://docs.gtk.org/gtk4/migrating-4to5.html#gtkstatusbar-is-going-away):

> ### GtkStatusbar is going away
> This is an old fashioned widget that does not do all that much any more, since it no longer has a resize handle for the window.

and it also has a strong opinion about [a11y roles](https://docs.gtk.org/gtk4/enum.AccessibleRole.html).

> Abstract roles are only used as part of the ontology; application developers **must not** use abstract roles in their code.

---

I may be wrong but it seems that `GtkStatusbar` does not use `GTK_ACCESSIBLE_ROLE_STATUS` either.

Agreed in the search case, but a gtk_accessible_announce could be nice if the status is not updated too often. What's the thing used for in the viewer case? This one at least look like a statusbar usage scenario... And, if the widget is the only place where status messages are displayed in the given window, I'd still made it a statusbar and did not care about the placement.
I am not sure about that. `GtkStatusbar` is used as a regular box in both cases. It is even located inside of a window and not at a bottom.
To at least keep the semantics, the boxes should have the GTK_ACCESSIBLE_ROLE_STATUS accessible role.To keep the semantic

note.body:
Hi Delpha. Thank you for creating this issue report. What exactly do you mean when you write "none of those [programs] work anymore"? Can you elaborate on that?

For example, what is the exact command you are running? How did you configure it in the program settings? What do you do to execute the custom command? And finally, when you run gnome-commander in a terminal, what is the output there when you execute the command? You can also try running gnome-commander with debug flags enabled. (`gnome-commander -d a`).

Thank you.
